newsitem.title: FRANCE: Computers that talk, or are simple and cheap?.
newsitem.headline: Computers that talk, or are simple and cheap?.

text.p: By Neil Winton, Science and Technology Correspondent

Bill Gates sees the day coming when your computer will listen, talk and learn, while Larry Ellison is offering a stripped-down device that give low-cost but narrowly-based access to information networks.
Industry observers see merit in the approaches of both these U.S. information technology leaders, saying there is almost certainly room for both as markets grow.
Microsoft Corp's Gates was giving his vision of the future to a conference here organised by IDG, the U.S. information technology consultancy and publisher.

Larry Ellison of database powerhouse Oracle Corp, was touting his Network Computer, the stripped-down device that offers low-cost but narrowly-based access to information networks. Ellison hopes that the network computer will help his often personalised campaign to topple Microsoft from its position as the dominant information technology company.
"His (Gates) job is to get Windows (software) everywhere. Our job is to make sure he doesn't," Ellison said.

Ellison, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Oracle, said in a speech that the personal computer is overpriced and overcomplicated and the much-heralded information age will never arrive if personal computers remain the only route to the Internet, the worldwide network of computers.
"Seventy percent of U.S. homes don't have a personal computer, and 90 percent of Europeans and Japanese don't have them. That leaves them effectively disenfranchised," Ellison said.
The information age will only arrive when access reaches television proportions of close to 100 percent, Ellison said.
Gates, chairman and Chief Executive Officer of software giant Microsoft Corp, said personal computers will continue to improve, providing more power, faster and cheaper.
"The pace of innovation is really pretty fantastic. The speed of processing is doubling every two years," Gates told IDG's "European IT Forum".
Computing power would provide unprecedented ease of access.
"We'll look back and say they (PCs) couldn't listen, they couldn't talk, they couldn't even learn," said Gates.
Ellison's vision of a product that would please the public was less grand.

"Myself and my mother were all the market research we (Oracle) did," said a straight-faced Ellison. "The product had to do all the things I wanted to do, like electronic mail, word processing, World Wide Web access and video conferencing, and be easy enough for her to use," Ellison said.
"It will do all the things better than the PC, at lower cost," Ellison said.
But industry observers see merit in the approaches of Microsoft and Oracle, saying there is almost certainly room for both as markets grow.
"The network computer is suitable for lots of things," said Neil Hollister, consultant at Datamonitor in London.
"Ellison's claim that there will be 100 million by 2000 is much too high, though. We say maybe eight to 10 million by 2000," Hollister said.
Some see hidden motives behind the push for a network computer.
"The creation of the NC specification is a politically motivated effort to accomplish a vendor-driven agenda," The Burton Group of Midvale, Utah, said in a recent report.
"The vendors involved, particularly Sun (Microsystems) and Oracle simply cannot stand the fact that Microsoft has so successfully dominated the PC industry," the report said.
"...the market has a way of crushing, or totally ignoring, such politically motivated efforts...", the report said.
Network computers will only occupy small market niches, The Burton Group said.
Ellison concedes that the network computer will never replace the PC, just as the PC failed to kill-off the mainframe computer.
"We just want computers to what we do better, easier, and cheaper," Ellison said.
